Translation: It is no longer necessary that someone become a teacher to learn Irish.

Question: From the above translation, what is a coilltearer?

Answer: A coilltearer is someone who spends time living in a cottage surrounded by plants and trees. They learn Irish from their teachers and become skilled in the language and culture.

Exercise 1:
True or False: The Teachta Dála passed a law stating that anyone could learn Irish.

Answer: True

Exercise 2:
What does the word "coilltearer" mean?

Answer: Someone who spends time living in a cottage surrounded by plants and trees.

Bho Dhihaoine, cha bhi biadh teth ri fhaotainn air bòrd nan soithicheall", a poem celebrating the beauty of their heritage, is a true reflection of his identity and the values that guide him.

Bho Dhihaoine's poems have won him many awards, including the coveted Chair for Poetry at the 2014 Celtic Literary Festival in California and the 2016 Máirtín Ó Cadhain Memorial Award. He has also had his poetry featured on BBC radio and television, gaining recognition and popularity for his unique and captivating style. His works have been translated into English and anthologies, showcasing the widespread appeal and relevance of his work.

Bha na trèanaichean, a bh' air an ainmeachadh às dèidh an Àrd-Àtha Cliath. This is the first official text of a bh' air, that of a "clan song". These songs are now generally referred to as ceoltóirí Chonaill, which is used to distinguish them from the ceoltóirí (Irish bagpipes), that had been introduced from Scotland in the early sixteenth century, and which are now much more important in the performance of traditional Irish music.

A short time after the compilation of this first known recording was made in 1932, the first modern Ceoltóirí Chonaill were founded. Through his extensive publications, he opened doors for students and scholars to learn about Irish history, culture, and language.

The recent boom in start-ups and tech giants, particularly on social media platforms, has created new types of employment and ways of working, often through the sharing economy. Although in Ireland most people are employed in the public sector, we are also seeing growth in the number of people in self-employment, the number of people working part-time, the number of people working flexibly and more people accessing various types of alternative or temporary forms of work.

The council of the Isles (; ) was one of seven territorial and administrative royal councils that comprised the Kingdom of the Isles. They were governed by the kings of Alba, the Gaelic kingdom established in Scotland during the eleventh century – and thus the council represents the earliest evidence for the existence of a royal government in the Hebrides. Founded by Godred Crovan and his allies, the council may have been a part of an existing system of royal governance in the Isles since its inception, or it may have constituted a separate, newly-established one. Whatever the case, the council's activities were limited to the islands of the Kingdom of the Isles, and included the Isles and Outer Hebrides as well as Argyll and possibly Ayrshire. Cha deach gin a chùis a dhearbhadh fhathast air a' Ghàidhealtachd.

The word "Cha" in Scots Gaelic means club or feast (Cha: a club; fhèis: a feast; dhearbhadh: the people gathering). The "Ghàidhealtachd" (Gaelic: Highlands) is the Highlands and Islands of Scotland, the "agh" is a plural form of agheas (Gaelic: a bower, or in this case, an open field) and "dhearbhadh" is plural of dheargadh (Gaelic: a feast).

In addition, there is a tradition of holding a different kind of feasting on Whitsun day, at which the head of a sheep is to be ceremonially presented.

References
A Dictionary of Modern Scottish Gaelic by Angus

Bho chaidh riaghailtean a chur an sàs feuch stad a chur air sgaoile laith.

The Irish Bho (bó) means 'a small stream' and chor (có) means 'the'. The name means little stream which passes over rocks.

A chur (coir) is a cross-branched piece of timber, and cúir (cún) is a kind of tree fern, and air 
(airth) means flowing water, and sgáith is the common gender of a city.

So the name means a little stream passing over the branches of a cúir tree and flowing to the flowing water of a city.

The Islands of Harris and St Kilda have experienced many hardships but remain resilient and continue to host many exciting opportunities for tourism and sustainable development. On an even larger scale, the islanders of North Uist and Tiree are also adapting to changes and embracing exciting new opportunities.
For many, this will also mean addressing their long standing energy needs. The islands of the Outer Hebrides depend overwhelmingly on oil and oil products to generate electricity and heat. This causes damage to the environment and to the islands' economy. However islanders have a special connection with the earth, a love of their islands and a vision of a brighter future.

Trial and execution
In 1259 after the Battle of Carham, Brian led a contingent of Galwegians under a banner of Saint Brendan to aid the Scots in their campaign against their English neighbours, the forces of Llywelyn ap Gruffudd.  Both armies were ambushed by the English on the banks of the River Dee.

Brian was captured and questioned at Berwick then moved to the Scots court of Mar at Dumfries. The English charged the Scots with conspiring to conquer England and threatened to destroy the country if Brian was not handed over for trial. The Anglo-Scottish treaty of 1259 required all captured Scotsmen to be returned to the land of their birth, however the Scots were aware that they could never release a captive English commander. Chaidh Toby, abhag Yorkshire a tha 13 bliadhna, a thoirt dhan bheat ann an Inbhir Narann (c. 1270 - 1344) () was a medieval Irish poet. His chief possession was the breac an Cnoc, a large fort in the townland of Kilkea, County Kildare.

Chaidh Toby was born at Keimre, Ardfert, County Kerry circa 1365. His father, Cuanach, was a royal clerk. He died in 1386, probably at the Battle of Lochaber, or shortly thereafter.

Chaidh wrote the following poem in his father's memory:

Translation:

My father, O lord, 
I do now regret,
O lord, how he was,
Thou didst leave from me;
My father, O lord,
How sad that thy servant's gone.

Climbing the castle

The castle offers stunning views of the River Tarbert and the countryside surrounding it. Visitors can climb the walls of the tower and enter the interior through a circular staircase, where they can explore the rooms and gardens. The ruins also have a special connection to William Butler Yeats, an Irish poet, as he spent part of his childhood there. You can even see the inscription on the floor that reads "YEARS OF PEACE 1649."

10. What role did Patrick Sarsfield play during the Glorious Revolution of 1688? 
Answer: Patrick Sarsfield was deployed to Ireland as Colonel of the cavalry to suppress the Catholic rebels' activities.

11. Who was Patrick Sarsfield's wife and how many children did they have? 
Answer: Patrick Sarsfield's wife was Catherine O'Toole and they had at least 10 children.

12. Who did Patrick Sarsfield support during the Williamite War in Ireland? 
Answer: Patrick Sarsfield supported James II
